June 8, 2008: Fiction
ODD HOURS, by Dean Koontz. (Bantam, $27.) Odd Thomas, who can
communicate with the dead, confronts evil forces in a California coastal town.
THE HOST, by Stephenie Meyer. (Little, Brown, $25.99.) Aliens have taken
control of the minds and bodies of most humans, but one woman won’t surrender.
LOVE THE ONE YOU’RE WITH, by Emily Giffin. (St. Martin’s, $24.95.) A woman’s
happy marriage is shaken when she encounters an old boyfriend.
THE FRONT, by Patricia Cornwell. (Putnam, $22.95.) A Massachusetts state
investigator and his team from “At Risk” confront a rogue association of municipal
police departments.
SNUFF, by Chuck Palahniuk. (Doubleday, $24.95.) An aging porn queen aims to
cap her career by having sex on film with 600 men in one day.
SUNDAYS AT TIFFANY’S, by James Patterson and Gabrielle Charbonnet. (Little,
Brown, $24.99.) A woman finds an unexpected love.
PHANTOM PREY, by John Sandford. (Putnam, $26.95.) The Minneapolis
detective Lucas Davenport investigates a string of murders of young Goths.
SWINE NOT?, by Jimmy Buffett. (Little, Brown, $21.99.) A Southern family tries to
hide its pet pig at a New York luxury hotel.
CARELESS IN RED, by Elizabeth George. (Harper, $27.95.) In Cornwall, trying to
recover from his wife’s death, Detective Thomas Lynley becomes involved in a
murder investigation.
THE WHOLE TRUTH, by David Baldacci. (Grand Central, $26.99.) An intelligence
agent and a journalist team up against a warmongering defense contractor.
INVINCIBLE, by Troy Denning. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $27.) The New Jedi order
battles Darth Caedus, Darth Vader’s grandson; a “Star Wars: Legacy of the Force”
novel.
BRIGHT SHINY MORNING, by James Frey. (Harper, $26.95.) A novel, set in Los
Angeles.
THE ART OF RACING IN THE RAIN, by Garth Stein. (Harper, $23.95.) A Lab-
terrier mix with great insight into the human condition helps his owner, a struggling
race car driver.
TWENTY WISHES, by Debbie Macomber. (Mira, $24.95.) A widow who owns a
bookstore on Blossom Street compiles a list of things she always wanted to do.

Non-Fiction
AUDITION, by Barbara Walters. (Knopf, $29.95.) A personal and professional
memoir.
ARE YOU THERE, VODKA? IT’S ME, CHELSEA, by Chelsea Handler. (Simon
Spotlight Entertainment, $24.95.) Humorous personal essays from the stand-up
comedian.
THE POST-AMERICAN WORLD, by Fareed Zakaria. (Norton, $25.95.) The rise of
China and India and the global distribution of power.
STOLEN INNOCENCE, by Elissa Wall with Lisa Pulitzer. (Morrow, $25.95.) The
star witness against the polygamous sect leader Warren Jeffs describes how he
forced her to marry her first cousin when she was 14.
THE REVOLUTION, by Ron Paul. (Grand Central, $21.) A libertarian manifesto
from the Texas congressman and Republican presidential candidate.
THE DOWNHILL LIE, by Carl Hiaasen. (Knopf, $22.) The Florida novelist takes up
golf again after 32 years.
A WOLF AT THE TABLE, by Augusten Burroughs. (St. Martin’s, $24.95.) A
memoir of life with a cruel father.
A TIME TO FIGHT, by Jim Webb. (Broadway, $24.95.) The Democratic senator
from Virginia offers his political vision.
COUNSELOR, by Ted Sorensen. (Harper, $27.95.) A memoir by John F.
Kennedy’s speechwriter and close aide, who was sometimes called a “deputy
president.”
ESCAPE, by Carolyn Jessop with Laura Palmer. (Broadway, $24.95.) A former
member of a fundamentalist polygamous sect describes her forced marriage.
ALWAYS BY MY SIDE, by Jim Nantz with Eli Spielman. (Gotham, $26.)
Remembering two decades with CBS Sports, with a focus on father-son
relationships.
HOME, by Julie Andrews. (Hyperion, $26.95.) A memoir of Andrews’s early years.
MY STROKE OF INSIGHT, by Jill Bolte Taylor. (Viking, $24.95.) A brain scientist
shares what she learned from her 1996 stroke, which produced a sense of
euphoria when it damaged her left brain.
UP TILL NOW, by William Shatner with David Fisher. (Thomas Dunne/St. Martin’s,
$25.95.) Captain Kirk’s autobiography.
